div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

div.head: TO-DAY'S ELECTIONS.
div.p: Whatever the result, the elections to the German Reichstag which take place today will greatly alter German policy abroad and administration at home. If the Government wins, increases the Navy and Army and a vigorous assertion of German Imperial rights will be the chief consequences. If the Government loses, the advocates of more world-power for the Kaiser will be silenced and the end of "personal rule" in Germany will be well in night.

The Government's prospects are rendered cheerless by the fact that the Catholic. Centre on which the Government has for years realised to secure the passing of its Bills in the Reichstag has joined the forces of the opposition. The Reichstag numbers 397 members. At its dissolution on December 13 the parties stood as follows:
Centre 100;
Social Democrats 81;
Conservatives 52;
National Liberals 50;

Free Liberals, Free Conservatives, Poles, Danes, Guelphia, Anti-Semites, Etc, 114. The government is seeking to replace the Centre with a coalition of Liberals and Conservatives, both of which parties are supporting the Government is the present campaign. The Social Democrats, evejn more than the Centre, are the objects of the Government's denunciations. But thet are the best-organised party in Germany, and it is more than doubtful if their numbers can be reduced, especially since the Centre has arranged with them to aboid contests between, the two parties when possible. The issue of to-day's great struggle is thus rendered the more interesting because it is no doubtful.
Let Them All Come.
Three Radical M.P.'s are expreted to arrive Egypt in the course of a few days.

div.head: THE RUSSIAN AGITATION.
div.p: APPEAL TO JEWS

Mr. Angelos Rohino Arbib, a Jewish notable of Cairo, is the author of an open letter to his brethrern, both at Alexandria and Cairo, in "Al Moayad." He urges them to give up demonstrations, which are a source of embarrassment to the local authorities and the British Occupation. Inasmuch as we are all subjects of alien Powers, he says, we have to right to be exacting, which we would have if we had a Goverment of our own. Under such circumstances we have to respect all Goverments and be obedient to their laws. If, contines Mr. Arbh, our Russian co-religionists are really criminal, we should help the Government in bringing them to justice lest our conduct leads to the death of thousands of innocent Jews in Russia.

div.head: HEDJAŻ RAILWAY.
div.p: RAPID PROGRESS.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT)
BEYROUT January 18.

The Hej z Railway has been making rapid strides of late. The Inspector General of the Imperial enterprise, Kiszm Pa-ha, has been Accompanying the sacred caravan to the uttermost limits of the line, with the view of studying the means best ca'onlated to recurs the comfort of the pilgrims travelling on the line. He has pushed on with his steff of engineers to kilometre 975, in Al'Ala, in the sacred vilayet of Al Hajz, within about 21 kilometres of Madayen Saleb Rails have been Isil op to kilometre 745, and over this long stretch trains now rony

The inangeration ceremony at Tehnk was referred to in the Press several weeks ago. The soldiers employed on the works seem to bave performed their duty in a praiseworthy manner hehin regard to technical ability and zeal, and it is expected that by the beginning of Febru ary ext. 755 kilometres will have been, completely laid. There tunnel work may retard operations mah, but suffiant labour has ben p'ared at bath ends of the trunel for sitantaneous work. One of the important fests worthy of record is the cathing throngh of a rocky stretch sbout 300 metres long and 11 high. The unusual hardues of this rock immt spécial vaine to the success of the underisking under conditions so very in favorable. and the pilgrims contemplatel this work with genuine The work of embankment is Langvigarasty pashad oa, and the amount) of work extraction carried out by the Imperia! sold er is estimated at about ous milion and ix hundred thousand cubic metres.

As the village of Al 'Ala contains about 700 all habitations and fair'y abundant waters, with rich produce, and as moreover it lies in the vicinity of the port of Al W-jh, on the Red Sea coast, it is destine i to have a proui-ing future. Indead, it is being then, ht more recommendable tha Madayen S.l-h for the building of a depot aid he's for the railway. Work on the Medius branch 1 to be started very shortly, and the neces swy implements and appliances are said to h. be already forwarded for the perpose. The pilgrims are beg uning to reap the benefits of this railway, and can now form an diate estimate of its importance when compied. Firmerly the holy caravan used to spend 30 daya in a difficult and slow march from Demasens to Medina, whereas now the Pilgrims may travel to Tebak on the line in every comfort, seeing that 10 trains are spe cially fitted and ran for them, then cross over to Medina on came! back, this arriving in 12 days in te d of 30 No wonder that the forvant Moslem, to whom the pilgrimage to h Holy City is a stepping stone to the Paraise of. Delights, shoalt aow look to the Imperial initiator of this grand and philanthro pi everprise wash deep and undying gratitude.

Cold winds and an overcast sky were the features of last week's weather in this ordinari y, sunny little spot in the desert. div.head: EGYPTIAN CONSTRUCTIONS, LIMITED. DEVELOPMENT OF THE COMPANY
div.p: We are informed that in addition to the firm of Messrs. Grant, Boudi and Chinn, sanitary and hot water engineers and army contractors, the firm of Messrs. Mark G. Boyes and Co., engineers, of Boulac, has also been acquired by the Egyptain Constructions, Limited, as from January 1, 1907. These two well-known firms will be conducted as branches of the company under the same management as in the past. Their acquisition marks an important development Anglo-Egyptian enterprise, and the increased facilities thus afforded to the company for carrying out every description of contracting and engineering works should prove advantageous to all concerened. The phenomenla growth of Messrs. Boyes business during the past few years is the strongest testimony to the satisfactory nautre of their work. Their workshops employ nearly 600 men and the demands of their business are constatnly adding to this number.

The name of Messrs. Grant, Bondi and Chinn is a synonym for all that is best in their trade, and they can for all that is best in their tradem and they can on substantial gorounds claim to be the first sanitary specialists in this country. They have exectued every imporatant sanitary installation in Egypt, besides carrying out contracts of note in Constantinople and the Red Sea for various quarantine stations. They have moreover held the British Government contracts for the Army of Occupation for the past eight years, and their contract has recently been renewed for another three years. Other important contracts and general development of the business has necessiated the strengthening of the working staff by the addition of a number of practical sanitary men from England and Italy, and there will shorlty be augmented by the arrival in Cairo of a futher number of expert workmen. These arrangements will enusre a continuation of the high efficiency of this business as a branch of the company.

A site has been acquired at Rod-el-Farag for the purpose of erecting new and commodious engineering works and stores, which will be the most complete and best equipped works in the hands of any private frim in Egypt, and these will be rapidly pushed forward to completion. In Alexandria the works and stores are being considerably extended and larger offices and showrooms have already been secured for Rosetta-street.
The large amount of work in hand sand the prosepcts genrally of the company suggest a large measure of future prosperity and warrant every confidence in its general management.

div.head: WESTERN OASIS RAILWAY.
div.p: All is activity at the Karusk have of the Western Oasis Railway, in prepartion for the exemption of work on platelaying next week. Owing to a shortage of material, a temporary breaks in the actual work of construction on was made, but as each day now passes a further supply is added to that already stacked at the base, and the arrival of material in a quantity suffiecient to pre-lude all possibility of futher delay having been assured, platelaying is to be at once vigorously pushed forward. The existing road is perfect, and offers exceptionally smooth running for a new railway of so narrow a gauge.

The average rate of contstruction being a kilometre a day, we may anticipate with conferences the early consummation fo this first phase of the great undertaking which lies in the hands of the Corporation of Western Egypt.

div.head: VICTORIA COLLEGE.
div.p: To The Editor Of The "Egyptian Gazette"

Sir,-I was walking a few days ago in the direction of the new building of the Victoria College, and as I drew near the consruction I noticed that the steel joissts for the college bore the mark of a Belgian firm, "Peiler Walzwark." I conclude therefore that this material I must be of Belgian origin. It amounted in quantity approximately to ten thousand tons. I naturally asked myself how it happened that the material for a college called iinto existence by British enterprise and generosity to commemorate our late Queen Victoria camt to be of foreign origin. I am curious to know who is responbsible for the fact that when the specifications were drawn up it was not stipulated that British material should be used. It is too be hoped that the committee of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt will take up the matter, and enquire how it is that the committtee of the Victoria College have been so negligent in looking after such an important point as the construction of the college with the help of British materials. Our own steel joists are recognized to be of the finest material and workmanship. The Belgian-made steel joists are of a plainer characcter and are consequently put on the market at a somewhat cheaper rate. The persons responsible for giving out the contract ought to have been most explicit is indicating that British steel joists were to be used. This is a good example of our listleness in endeavouring to push our own industry, and if there are any business men on the committee of the college they ougt to be asked why they were so remiss in looking after their country's trade interests. Lord Cromer's attention ought to be drawn to the matter. Truly yours. A Casual Visitor

div.head: BRITISH PRESTIGE.
div.p: To The Editor Of The "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir,- Sunday's demonstration afforded one striking object-lesson that your anti-British Nationalists may well take to heart. It is that however much our foes may howl us down, it is after all to Great Britain that humanity appeals when hard pressed. Not only in Egypt, but in Persia, Turkey, Russia, everywhere, in fact, where oppression reigns political refugees fly to the Union Jack for freedom. Yours, etc.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY.
div.p: NOTICE

Owners of bicycles, tricycles, motor cycles, and hand carts, including barrel organs, are informed that numbered plaques will be supplied to them free by the Municipality. For those who hold a plaque for 1906 a distinctive mark for 1907 will be added. Applications must be made to the Service des Recettes before February 18, 1907, Sundays and holidays excepted, by the owners, so as to the have the plaques or distinctive marks put on to their vehicles. After the above date, if any of the above mentioned vehicles are found circulating without a plaque or distinctive mark their owners will be liable to prosectution. 29400-5-2

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: It is not generally known that Lord Erington, Lord Cromer's eldest son, can claim to represent the senior line of the ancient house of Stanley, which is not represented by the Lords of Derby. The head-ship rested with the late Sir John Stanley Errington, twelfth and last haronet, of Hooton who died several years ago. His brother and predeccessor lived to see his two daughters married, one to the Earl of Cromer and the other to the Earl of Mexborough, so that Lady Cromer's son, Viscount Errington, could probably claim to be head of the house of Stanley.

div.head: EARTHQUAKE AT JAMAICA. FRESH SHOCKS FELT.

div.p: Two shocks of earthquake were felt yesterday, which were the severest since the 14th instant. Several buildings collapsed. There were no further casualties. Great alarm was felt. H.M.S. Brilliant and the French and Haytian cruisers have arrived with supplies. (Reuter)

Mr. Bacon in a Note to the British Charge d'Affaires, Mr. Howard, hastens to assure him on behalf of Mr. Roosevelt that the American Government pays no heed whatever to the Jamaican incident. It much appreciates the tank and ready courtesy shown in Sir. E. Grey's despatch. It is espeically gratifying, he said to the President "to feel it has been possible for America to show her friendship towards a community of your people in time of suffering." (Reuter)

div.head: THE COLD IN EUROPE DEATHS IN PARIS STREETS.

div.p: Vessels arriving in Channel ports are completely ice-mautled. Deaths have occurred in the streets in Paris. The Italian Lakes and Venetian canals are frozen over. (Reuter)
Telegrams show that intense cold prevails throughout Europe. (Havas)

div.head: SENSATIONAL LONDON MURDER. "UNIVERSAL PROVIDER" SHOT DEAD.

div.p: Mr. Whiteley of the "Universal Provider Stores," was shot dead when going to his lunch by a young man, who immediatley after the deed committed suicide.
Later.

Mr. Whiteley's assailant is still alive he alleges that he is a son of Mr. Whiteley, but he is unknown to the family. The murder followed a stormy interview in Mr. Whiteley's room. The room was crowded, but he was cheated, and has been closed. (Reuter)

The Italian and French Ambassadors have informed the Porte that the Dominican religious establisments here, and the Franciscan missions in Tripoli and Baros, have been transferred to Italian protection. (Reuter)
The Archbishop's Palace has been converted into offices for the new Ministry of Labour. (Reuter)
The cabinet has resigned. (Havas)
The resignation of Signor Martini Governor of Erythres, has been accepted from 25th March next, when Marquis Salvago-Baggi Consul General at Zanzibar, will replace him. (Reuter)
The Senate, which is discussing the Budget, has reduced the stamp duty on foreign stocks to 1.50 francs. (Havas)
The French and Spanish squadrons have sailed. Each squadron has left a guardship behind.
The Imperial trrops attacked the beni Msuar tribe yesterday and burned five villages. They met with no opposition. Whilst returning the hillsmen sniped them, killing 9 men and wounding 15. (Reuter)
The French and Spanish squadrons have left. (Havas)

div.head: GERMANY AND DENMARK AMELIORATION OF RELATIONS.

div.p: The German Danish Treaty, in respect to Danish subjects, is considered as a proof that a real amelioration of the relations between the two countries has taken place. The newspapers publish numerous extracts from Copenhagen papers taking the same view. The public consider that by this Treaty Denmark has definitely made peace with Germany. The Treaty has been made at the express wishes of the King of Denmark and the Emperor William. From the time of his appointment Herr Tschirschky has sought to bring about the realization of these wishes. (Reuter)

div.head: AMERICAN FOREIGN TRADE. MESSAGE TO CONGRESS.

div.p: President Roosevelt has sent a special message to Congress urging legislation to assist American shipping by building and running lines of large swift steamers to South America and the Orient, in order to avoid the surrender of trade to commercial rivals. (R.)
Mr. McKenna will have a seat in the Cabinet. There is a persistent rumour that Mr. Winton Churchill will replace Mr. McKenna as Financial Secretary to the Treasury. (Reuter)
The Chamber has passed the bill covering by an issue of 141 millions of Rente, the credit for the reorganisations of the marine artillery. (Havas)

div.head: THE SPHINX.
div.p: Mr. Alex B. Tulloch writes from Biarritz to the "Globe":- In one of your late issues you refer to the age of the Sphix, or rather I should say to the date of its construction. May I mention that some 20 years ago I sent a short note to the "Egyptian Gazette" suggesting that the Sphinx was the origin or cause of the rection of the Pyramids of the Kinds on the plateua behnd the Sphinx. The general idea is that the Sphix is the oldest known artistic monument in the world, and that it was formely worshipped possibly as a representative of the life giving Nile. If that be really the case, then there would be some reason for the royal tombs being placed always under its shadow, just as in medieval times people of position were buried in the chancels of cathedrals and churches, as near the altar as possible, and those of lesser degree in the body of the church. As the sun's position so to say changes during the year, the Sphinx, which lies to the eastward of the great burial plateau, would have its shadow swept over the whole of the Pyramids and grave chambers to the west of it. I may be and probably am, rather visionary in my idea that the Sphinx is the origin of the Pyramids. Perhaps some of your readers may also have some opinions on the subject. As for the Sphinx having a head-dress or ornament indicating some special dynasty, may not that speciality have been made or altered to suit this reing of some particular king, as Egyptian monuments or records have been so tampered with. In our own coinage the national or Royal arms remain the same on one side, but the head of the sovereign changes.

div.head: THE MONEY MARKET.
div.p: After standing at 6 percent for about 14 weeks, the Bank rate was yesterday reduced to 5 percent. This action of the directors is by no means received with favour in all quarters as, although it will enable traders to get business that is going, it will not have so strong a tendency to attract money to London. In addition to that, there is considerable doubt as to the financial position in America, and pressure for money in that quarter within a month or so is not at all improbable. During the past twelve months the demand for money in America has been enhanced by a number of events, foremost among which must be reckoned the San Francisco earthquake, which absorbed an enormous sum. Then, too, the remarkable prosperity of the country has been a constant drain; and it is reasonable to expect that unless the United States Treasury makes some more serious attempt to give assistance to the market, the Bank of England will ere long be again drawn upon to a considerable extent.

There is, however no probabillity of anythinng approaching a panic, and the Bank position is so strong as to preclude the likelihood of the directors being compelled to recur, for some time to come, to a six percent rate, having once reduced it.

The Bank return this week again shows a substantial increas in the reserve, which, notwithstanding the extraction of over a million for abroad, is 1,174,000 higher at 22,593,449. There has been a considerable reflux of currency from the country, the stock of bullion habing increased by 508,000. The note circulation shows a contraction of 666,000. In consequence of the repayments by the market to the Bank, private deposits are down to 3,125,000 and "Other" securities are down just under 3,000,000. The proportion of reserve to liabilities has risen 5.5 percent to 45.75 percent.

div.head: The Stock Markets.
div.p: For some weeks past there has been, among a certain of the "House," a constant clamour for induction in the Bank rate and it has been confidently asserted that there would be no improbement in the volume of investment business until such a reduction was made notwithstandiing the fact that a steady advance in the value of securitiees was meanwhile noticeable. The rate has now been lowered, but those members who have imagined that such action on the part of the Bank directors would be followed by a prompt spurt in Stock Exchange business have been disappointed, while those who habe followed carefully the sequence of events in the financial situation, and have made the best of matters during the period of tight money, find their anticipations justified. As we have said before, it is useless to depend upon a substantial easing of the monetary position for an increase in investment operations, and iin the best informed cirlces it is recognised as by no means certain the present ease will continure for nay lenglty period.

The announcement of the Bank rate decision yesterday, as we have hinted, had little effect upon markets, which developed a rather irregular tone. Today there has been no sign of improvement; on the contrary, there has been an easing off in several directions. This may probably be accounted for by the fact that in the early part of the week there was considerable buying in anticipation of a reduction in the rate, and the fforts which habe since been made to secure profits upon the news have met with failure.
The undertone is nevertheless, sound in all sections, and a return ot the active conditions which prevailed at the commencement of the yar may soon be expected.

div.head: Consols.
div.p: The easing of the monetary situation, and confident anticipations of a substantial reduction in the Bank rate, appreciably assisted gilt-edged stocks, and Consols have shown a steady rise. Curiously enough, yesterday's decision had little effect upon the premier security which, after hardening 1/16 relapsed to the previous day's price, 87 ¼. The closing quotation tonight fo rthe account is 87 1/8 a loss of 1/8.

div.head: Foreign Bonds.
div.p: Russian bonds have displayed strength, despite pessimistic statements which have appeared in some of the newspapers heave regarding the present financial situation in Russia. There now appears to be much more confidence in an ealry return to tranquility in that ocuntry, at any rate among financiers, who doubtless have good reason for their optimism, and it is to be hoped that heir position may be justified by subsequent events.

The script of the new Fives is rather easier tonight at 3 3/8 and the Fours at 78 ¼. Japanee issues continue firm, and yesterday the 4 ½ perecent. (First Series) further advanced 1/8 to 97 7/8 the Japan Industrial Bank 3/16 to 8, and there was a rise of 1/8 in two other stocks.
The foreign market generally hahs been neglected today.

div.head: Home Ralls
div.p: The home railway market has in the main be in steady, though a few of the hsares have displayed a somewhat erratic tendency during the past two days. Yesteday South Western issues, after being irregular, came into renewed favour, the Ordinary advancing a full point to 155 ½, and the Deferred ¼ to 54 ¾.
Today the market has been dull, and South Western Ordinary and Deferred declined I, South Eastern "A", 1, while most of the shares have shown smaller losses.

div.head: Americans.
div.p: The tendency in the American railway market has again been in a downward direction, owing to the continued liquidation in Wall Street. The New York market, as we stated last week, is in a nevous state, hence adverse remours have played a prominent part in the movements, the statements regarding the health of Mr. Pierpout Morgan being a weakening point.

Yesterday the maket here opened better, and continued steady until the early New York advices came over, but then relapsed. Southern Railway Preference were very weak, losing 7 points to the 88. Illinois Central and Wabash "B" Debeutrues dropped 2, and Chicago Great Western at Louisville 1.5.
The American market today has been irregular, but the majoirty of changes are to lower levels.

Ces actions numerotees de 60,001 a 120,000 seront smieses jouissance ler Janvier 1907.
E les auront les memes droits et avanta es les actions de capital existances.

1. SOUSCRIPTIONS PRIVILECIES ET IRREDUCTIBLES.
Tout prteur de DEUX ACTIONOS anciennes (capital on dividende) a le droit de souscrize une action de capital nouvelle.

Les actions nouvelles. pour lequelles ete droit de prefference n'aura pas ete exerce, serout repartissentre les actionnaires anciencs qui les reclamerout par une souscription speciale eventuelle et reductible.
Ces actions eront reparties au prorats des anciene titres posseddee par les souscripteurs sans que la limite indulquee par eux dans leurs souscriptions reductibles puisse etre depasse.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: LAKE OF LUCERNE. Grand Hotel, Axen-Fels.
div.p: Best Spring resort. 2,200 ft. above the sea. Every comfort.

The leading Hotel for English and American families. Trains every fifteen minutes by Electric Railway from Brunnen to Axen-Fels. The Park having a frontage of nearly a mile on the lake, is one of the prettiest in Switzerland.
World-wide reputation.
P: Sohnack, Proprietor
Level Wooded Walks.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL DES BAINS.
div.p: Adjoining the sea. First-class hotel with dependencies & chalets. 200 rooms & saloons. Electric light. Aqueduct. Every modern comfort. Delightful residence, without any mosquitos.

div.head: THE GRAND HOTEL LIDO.
